sect1.title: What You Need Before Getting Started
sect1.para: As of this writing, this text only describes installing and using Reia under Linux. It is assumed that you already know how to find and install software on your choosen Linux distribution both through your distributions package manager and from source. It is also assumed that you are somewhat confortable with tools such as Git and Rake and will be able to do some basic troubleshooting if things don't work quite as expected. If any of this does not describe you, you should probably expect to have a harder time following along.

sect1.title: Installation
sect1.para:
As it is still in the early stages of development, installing Reia is not quite as smooth as many more mature languages which can be installed directly from your package manager. In order to install Reia you are first going to need to compile it from source. To do that, your going to need a few basic components:
Erlang R12B-3 or greater
Ruby 1.8.7 or greater with Rake
Git
First, we'll need to checkout the GitHub repository. To do so run: git clone https://github.com/tarcieri/reia.gityour output should look something like:Cloning into reia... remote: Counting objects: 8727, done. remote: Compressing objects: 100% (3343/3343), done. remote: Total 8727 (delta 5380), reused 8590 (delta 5296) Receiving objects: 100% (8727/8727), 7.25 MiB | 759 KiB/s, done. Resolving deltas: 100% (5380/5380), done.Great! Now change to the newly created directory. It should look something like: If all is well you should now be able to build Reia itself. To do so simply run:rakeThis both builds Reia and runs the test suite.
